ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It's great for those interested in the subject matter. It's a very narrow course, so if you don't like the first and second classes, you won't like any of them.

I would say that this class is a nice way to someone who wants to take some sort of Judaic Studies class to be exposed to an environment where you get to talk about Jewish texts in a low pressure environment. There was almost no work all semester long, until one very big final paper that was very frustrating to write because it was incredibly open-ended and the expectations were pretty unclear as to what we were supposed to do. It was also a little hard to have a 2 hour class that started at9:20 in the morning, and Professor Fraade could sometime go on and lose us a little. However, I did enjoy the class, the subject matter was interesting, and it was a great way to fulfill your language requirement if you don't want to start a new language from scratch and already know Hebrew.

An interesting introduction to the academic study of Rabbinic texts. You definitely learn a lot about how the Midrash works and its textual intricacies. Class discussions often dragged a little bit. But Professor Fraade is such a kind and patient teacher! He is very willing to meet outside of class, e.g. to discuss your final paper. Weekly preparation is minimal but the final paper (15-20 pages) takes a significant investment of time and thought.
This was a great class for anyone interested in studying an ancient rabbinic text - you get to learn about it both from a religious perspective and an academic one.
